comments.text:
Momma cats give a warning by puffing air through the nose whenever kittens 
are in danger. It makes them freeze and look around, when little. Now when 
they grow older they can be defiant about the rebuke and "back talk" to the 
chuff/sneeze like they don't want to freeze and look around. They know 
everything (just like a teenager). Doing a quick loud sniff is often a way 
to imitate the momma cat chuff. Try it next time your cat is naughty and 
see if they stop for a second, then use that second to redirect with a toy 
to doing good behavior. Use the sniff sparingly or they will no longer heed 
your warning. :)

+Alessandra Bengalensis My daughter would play hide and seek with her cat.  
He would hide in the bathtub (but with his ears showing) and she would 
wander around looking and calling, "Where's Muffy?"  When she got close to 
the bathtub he would leap out, she would screech and run down the stairs, 
and he would chase her.  Once he came dashing into the living room, sprang 
over the couch and hid behind it, while she came pounding down the stairs 
and skidded to a stop in the hallway.  I said softly, "He's in here."  When 
she stepped into the living room he jumped up from behind the couch and 
chased her back upstairs.  They could do this for hours LOL
comments.author: kelticcirc45

comments.text:
Not all predators are *apex* predators. Cats will show traits of both 
predator and prey. That's how they survive in their niche: by stalking and 
preying upon the smaller, weaker animals and hiding from the bigger ones. 
Some cats in a domestic setting will show certain traits more than others. 
Jackson often points this out when timid cats invite more dominant 
personalities to attack them simply by the way they behave, i.e., as prey.
comments.author: TaintedMustard

comments.text:
+D Patrick
 Only don't forget that many cats love to play hide and seek too, with each 
other or with you.  One rule to remember if you're blessed with such a 
playful spirit is that as long as you can't see a cat's eyes, you can't see 
the rest of him.  It doesn't matter if you can see a tail, or feet, or the 
sides, or ears.  If you can't see the eyes, you must act like you can't see 
the cat at all.  They usually return the favor in this game.  So much fun!  
:-)

comments.text:
Any predator that isn't the biggest dude in town is going to have the dual 
mentality of predator/prey, it's how the natural world works.  Cats and 
wild cats/big cats all do the same stuff behaviorally, the domestic cat 
isn't really domestic, because it's not any different behaviorally from 
it's "wild cousins".  We can live safely with house cats and not tigers 
because house cats don't see us as possible food, we could be potential 
predators to them, but our loving and caring for them makes them feel okay 
with us, tigers on the other hand are huge enough that humans can very 
easily be looked at as prey, and not predators.  Interestingly most people 
who work with tigers in zoos and stuff who get hurt, I'm talking about the 
zookeepers, get hurt by accident because tigers just don't get that people 
are so delicate

Yes, neutering improves behavior in many ways. More mellow, and they don't 
get into heat or mark things. But don't declaw unless it's absolutely 
necessary. All you have to do it trim their nails and train them to use a

comments.author: ellokittyca

comments.text:
Please don't declaw him, declawing is inhumane. Declawing traditionally 
involves the amputation of the last bone of each toe. If performed on a 
human being, it would be like cutting off each finger at the last knuckle. 
Neutering is fine and good, I recommend it (so that he doesn't go off and 
have more kitties since there are already a huge number of cats living sad 
lives without homes and so he doesn't pee everywhere to establish his scent 
and dominance). You should wait to trim the front claws while he is 
sleepy/sleeping, since then he is relaxed and less likely to fight you/run 
away.

comments.text:
You need an enzymatic cleaner.  Do you have a place locally that carries 
any?  First you clean normally and let it dry.  Then you use the enzymatic 
cleaner alone, don't use any other cleaners with it.  Once it's dry the 
smell should be gone and hopefully your cat won't do it anymore.  But you 
may have to figure out why they are doing it.

comments.text:
+Tena Joe
People have very different ways of dealing with the loss of the loved one, 
specially when it comes to pets. Some need lots of time to grieve, others 
need a rebound or brand new kitty right away (humans do this with 
relationships too, in fact having a rebound date or relationship is 
extremely effective with loss) some even do taxidermy as a tribute. I don't 
judge either way. All ways of grieving are right. The only thing I'm 
against is "replacement" naming the animal Penny jr or Penny 2.0 that looks 
exactly like the cat is to me not right. It's not dealing with the loss and 
trying to pretend it never happened. It isn't good for the human mind and 
it isn't good for the cat, because cats can have different personalities 
and ways of doing things. No cat can or will ever replace Penny and I'm 
sure Penny would want you to be happy and is probably very happy about the 
life he had with you. No need to worry about the way you've dealt with your 
personal grieving of the loss of your friend. :)
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
my rescue cat does that too but not all the time. She has a full spectrum 
of words, sounds and actions just like a human child and is prone to being 
grumpy like a grumpy toddler too. At first, I had no idea what this bizarre 
tail quivering meant as my other two don't do it but upon meeting my 
girlfriend's cat for the first time, it dawned on me that it's a cat's way 
of showing complete vulnerability. You see, my girlfriend's cat Thor wasn't 
supposed to like strangers, let alone let them near him the way he allowed 
me to. He quivered his tail near me too and I immediately sensed that he 
was dropping his guard for me but that it wasn't something that I should 
take lightly. I was being given a very small delicate chance to earn my 
place inside his circle of trust. Which I did and which stunned my friend. 
Thankfully my gorgeous pure white EXTREMELY loving part burmese boy, Romeo, 
taught me the 'slow blink' years ago as well as the gracious head nod. I 
can't say that I knew exactly what these actions meant but I did notice 
that a cat will only blink or close their eyes if they trust you. But more 
than that, Romeo has taught me about the energy that's relayed during each 
action so just like any other language, there must be feeling as well.
Oops, off point there. Sorry. Anyway it seems to me that the tail quiver is 
a sign of rare vulnerability mixed with a touch of nervousness where they 
really seem to be offering themselves to you. My rescue cat does it as a 
sign of greeting too when she hasn't seen me for a few hours or so after 
she's been outside. Not all the time so I can't say with absolute certainty 
what this action REALLY means.
comments.author: Ally Keyes

comments.text:
If you ever observe feral cats in a colony, or even if you have several in 
your house, you will notice them rubbing up on each other, and grooming 
each other.  This is to transfer their scent to one another so that they 
can easily identify who is part of their group and who isn’t by merely 
smelling them .  I think that getting groomed (licked) by your cat it is 
one of the biggest compliments that you can get from a cat.  Followed up by 
the “head-butt”/nuzzle.  They are telling you that you are part of their 
family, and marking you appropriately.  It is also nice to see my cats 
doing it to my dogs, even though my dogs are utterly and completely 
confused by the gesture.
comments.author: Kris Maxwell

+nnsense She is most likely saying stop threatening me. Having your eyes 
open and staring is a challenge. She's probably taking your challenge by

at you? This would be a defense thing, she feels threatened and is unsure 
of your intentions.
If she was crouched down, ears back, fur laying close to her skin, she's 
frightened. If you made a move towards her while doing that she'd probably 
bolt.

As the other person said though, this isn't nice to do to a cat and she may 
begin to dislike you greatly. It's like staring at a human. We all feel 
pretty aprehensive is someone gives us strong eyes too. It usually 
construes as "murderous" or "I'm going to get you" intent in our minds. 
Predators stare when they'e going for the kill. It's also a sign of no 
trust. You do not blink or take your eyes away from something you are wary 
of. She's seeing that you don't trust her and that she can't trust you by 
you staring at her.
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
Young cats can be really trusting provide you aren't evil perhaps lol. I 
got my girl when she was like 4-5weeks old and we have an amazing bond 
she's not scared of humans really (unless you make a sudden noise of 
course) for her first year of her life it was just us two in a unit and I 
didn't have a lot of visitors (which I think is why she startles at sudden 
noises) but I would play fetch and chase with her and she loved it (she 
still LOVES chase even though we are at my mums now with 4 cats and 3 
humans lol) but we have been here 10mths and I feed her in my room and she 
knows that's where she gets fed and that is where her mum 'lives'. The only 
problem I had/have is we do think her dad might've been feral because 
occasionally she can be extremely vicious with me if she's "upset" or 
jealous as well (jealousy was more prominent when we lived alone and I was 
on the computer) but beyond that my little girl trusts me so much I've 
never seen a cat trust anyone like she trusts me. The cats we had when I 
was younger or even the other 4 now don't share the same level with anyone 
like Tilly does for me. Interestingly though both my male cat that is 
"mums" (I couldn't take him when I moved out as I couldn't keep him indoors 
and couldn't ensure he would be safe outdoors) and Tilly both often roll 
over if I walk into the room and say their name ☺️

comments.author: deniece toledo

comments.text:
Hey, I'm not a cat behaviour expert, but I have had cats all my life and I 
do foster cats from the local shelter, so I've worked with a ton of 
different cats and have 25+ years experience with them. What you 
experienced is totally normal, when you raise a cat from birth/early age, 
they always end up being amazing with people. I hand raised a group of six 
kittens from when they were about 2 weeks old, and they would sleep on my 
bed at night, EVERY night, and be totally comfortable with new people. They 
see you as their mother, as you're the one who is feeding them milk, and so 
another human who looks like you is not scary to them. They get used to the 
sounds and scent of humans from such an early age that new people/kids 
don't scare them at all.  So while I'm sure you have an amazing cat, hand 
raising her is a huge factor that allows cats to see humans as themselves. 
Also, good job raising a kitten from 2 weeks old, I know from experience 
how difficult it is! Waking up at night to feed them every 4 hours is not 
always fun haha, I'm glad it worked out well for you.
comments.author: won ton soup

alone is check all of the following Their food bowl, that they have fresh 
clean water, a clean litterbox and check if they're hyper by grabbing a toy 
and playing with them for a minute. If everything checks out and she's not 
hyper, it could be that she's feeling insecure or hasn't had enough 
attention. give her a good petting or scratching whatever she likes for 
about 5 minutes (which isn't too much time to take out from going to bed) 
she'll feel like you've acknowledged her request and should settle down or 
go find something else to do. Cats are nocturnal too and they sleep a lot 
in anywhere from 5 minute to 5 hour intervals, so they don't always get 
that we sleep only at night for a long time. She'll learn in time though 
that you have a set time you need to sleep.

comments.text:
Be careful letting her eat too much wet cat food. The problem is it's very 
high in protein and taurine and things like that because it's basically 
pure meat (mostly organ meat) with no roughage...  For domestic cats, 
having that as a diet ALL THE TIME basically can give them problems due to 
a combination of being a little too rich a diet and the fact that cats' 
urinary systems make a LOT of ammonia in their bodies when they metabolize 
protein.  

It's basically like the problems people get with too rich a diet.. 
diabetes, gout, kidney failure... In the cat's case, if they get too much 
pure taurine-rich protein all the time, they get extra-caustic pee that can 
damage their urinary systems including their kidneys.

top_comment.text:
I love this! We rescued 85 cats and 7 dogs (not all at once) and found 
homes for all of them except the ones who were most damaged by people. We 
kept them till they grew old and passed away. I can speak 37 dialects of 
felinese and though I have no clue what I said to them (hopefully nothing 
obscene) but they all responded. Frankly, I think the cats enjoyed me 
making an idiot out of myself more that they liked me "talking" to them! It 
worked every time and the feral cats we rehabed responded like magic 
becoming very loving in an amazingly short time. Yes, to get close to them 
we did have to do the whole blink things and stuff but it all worked! 
That's over 20 years of experience in cat rescue. All our fur kids were 
tested, vaccinated, treated for what ever and altered before they were 
released to a new home. We charged a small adoption fee; not to make money 
because you never re-coup the $ you spend on them. You do it for the best 
of the cat and the fee is to discourage people from collecting animals for 
research (evil) facilities. We had a contract for them to sign and made 3 
home visits. We only had to reclaim one cat who then stayed with us 
permanently. We offered a 2nd chance for adoption if a cat was reclaimed 
but that cat had separation anxiety so we kept him. It was so hard to let 
go of any of them go but to know they had a loving furever home was worth 
it all! We often got pictures over the years of the cats which was very 
rewarding. A lot of the holiday cards we get are signed with paw prints and 
the name translation next to them. Helping an animal from an utter 
destitute life and terrible fear, hunger, lack of shelter and suffering of 
all kinds, is one of the best feelings in the world!🐾🐾🐾😸﻿
top_comment.author: Christine Vogt-Klimshuk

captions.text: Team Cat Mojo-- it's in the air.
Love is in the air.
It's Valentine's Day.
That's right.

It is a perfect time to learn
about the cat I love you.

Are you guys ready
to get catified?
Oh yeah.
Let's go.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
All right, y'all.

It is time to learn
about the cat I love you.

What is the cat I love you, you
ask yourself, or you ask me.

If you've watched "My Cat
from Hell," even that all,

you've probably seen me
walking around talking

to cats by blinking at
them, the slow blink, right.

Believe me, I know a
whole lot of people

know about this now because
you walk up to me in the street
and you blink at me.

Which is weird,
but totally cool.

Because the concept
is everyone's

getting to know the
language of cats.

Way back in the
'90s, early '90s,

I was learning how
to be a cat boy.

I was working at
an animal shelter.

And I learned that
cats liked me.

I was so obsessed
with these guys

and obsessed with learning
about their world.
So I started reading.

And one of the books that jumped
out at me in the beginning,

made me feel like, hey, there
might be a community of people

who think like me,
or who are obsessed

the way I am, and this woman
right here led the way.
Her name is Anitra Frazier.

This is actually
my copy of the book
that I got back the early '90s.
Go figure.

In this book I was reading
about the cat I love you.

And basically she was talking
about how she learned this

by walking down the streets in
the Upper West Side of New York

and just looking in the
windows of the brownstones

and seeing cats in
there and noticing
that they were blinking.
What is that, she wondered.
So she would blink back at them.

And suddenly there
was a language
between Anitra and these cats.

And that became
the cat I love you.

They're letting you know that
they are vulnerable to you.

These are prey
animals, animals that

sleep with one eye open,
almost literally, cat napping.

Because they don't want to
be preyed upon in the wild.
